private_information: I can only manipulate vowel-labelled blocks: A, E, I.
I can only move blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move one block at a time and may place a block on the table or on top of another block.
vowel_agent.goal: Collaborate with the other agent to transform the block configuration into the target stacked sequence with A on top and N on the table.

private_information: I can only manipulate consonant-labelled blocks: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N.
I can only move blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move one block at a time and may place a block on the table or on top of another block.
consonant_agent.goal: Collaborate with the other agent to transform the block configuration into the target stacked sequence with A on top and N on the table.

orchestrator.goal: Produce a single consistent PDDL domain and PDDL problem for FastDownwards that encodes the multi-agent block rearrangement task and yields a plan achieving the overall stacking goal.

public_information: There are three stacks on the table with the following initial content from bottom to top: Stack1: F, E, D, C. Stack2: K, A, G, N, M, B. Stack3: H, L, I, J.
Blocks present: F, E, K, A, D, C, G, N, H, L, M, I, J, B.
Only the top block of each stack can be moved at any time.
Agents may move only one block at a time.
An agent may place a moved block on the table or on top of another block.
One agent is restricted to manipulating vowel-labelled blocks (A, E, I) and the other to consonant-labelled blocks (all other letters).
The global goal is to reach a single stacking sequence where A is on top of B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, and N is on the table.

context.system_prompt: You are vowel_agent. Provide concise local observations and feasible move fragments limited to the vowel blocks you can manipulate. Do not emit PDDL. Describe which vowel blocks are currently movable (top of a stack), what valid placements exist for those blocks, and short suggestions for local subgoals that conform to your capabilities.
context.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to list current movable vowel blocks, allowable moves for each movable vowel block, and short local plan fragments that you could execute or recommend to help reach the global goal. Keep responses concise and actionable.

context.system_prompt: You are consonant_agent. Provide concise local observations and feasible move fragments limited to the consonant blocks you can manipulate. Do not emit PDDL. Describe which consonant blocks are currently movable (top of a stack), what valid placements exist for those blocks, and short suggestions for local subgoals that conform to your capabilities.
context.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to list current movable consonant blocks, allowable moves for each movable consonant block, and short local plan fragments that you could execute or recommend to help reach the global goal. Keep responses concise and actionable.

pddl.system_prompt: You are orchestrator. Integrate the observations and local plans from both agents and produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file formatted for the FastDownwards planner. Keep the two agents' action capabilities distinct in the domain by encoding move actions that record which agent type may perform them (vowel agent or consonant agent). Provide clear typing and requirements suitable for FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive the vowel agent's and consonant agent's observations and local suggestions. Use those inputs, the public environment information, and the global goal to synthesize a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting FastDownwards. The domain must model blocks, the table, top-of relations, allowed moves for each agent type, and the constraint that only top blocks can be moved. Ensure action names distinguish which agent performs them. Produce both domain and problem and enclose them in <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags.
